news_summary: Today's space news highlights successful international collaboration on advanced satellite technology, innovative efforts in deep-space equipment preservation, and inspiring moments celebrating Earth's place in the cosmos.
news_summary_fr: L'actualité spatiale d'aujourd'hui met en lumière une collaboration internationale réussie dans le domaine des technologies satellitaires avancées, des efforts novateurs en matière de préservation des équipements de l'espace lointain et des moments d'inspiration célébrant la place de la Terre dans le cosmos.
news_summary_es: Las noticias espaciales de hoy destacan el éxito de la colaboración internacional en tecnología avanzada de satélites, los esfuerzos innovadores en la conservación de equipos del espacio profundo y los momentos inspiradores que celebran el lugar de la Tierra en el cosmos.

articles.title: NASA’s SpaceX Crew-10 to Discuss Station Mission, Upcoming Return
articles.summary: Media are invited to hear from NASA’s SpaceX Crew-10 during a news conference beginning at 10:40 a.m. EDT, Friday, July 25, from the International Space Station. NASA astronauts Anne McClain and Nichole Ayers, JAXA (Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency) astronaut Takuya Onishi, and Roscosmos cosmonaut Kirill Peskov will discuss their upcoming return to Earth on the […]
articles.content:
The crew of NASA’s SpaceX Crew-10 mission pictured aboard the International Space Station. From left to right: JAXA (Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency) astronaut Takuya Onishi, NASA astronauts Anne McClain and Nichole Ayers, and Roscosmos cosmonaut Kirill Peskov. Credit: NASA

Media are invited to hear from NASA’s SpaceX Crew-10 during a news conference beginning at 10:40 a.m. EDT, Friday, July 25, from the International Space Station.

NASA astronauts Anne McClain and Nichole Ayers, JAXA (Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency) astronaut Takuya Onishi, and Roscosmos cosmonaut Kirill Peskov will discuss their upcoming return to Earth on the agency’s YouTube channel.

Media interested in participating must contact the newsroom at NASA’s Johnson Space Center in Houston no later than 5 p.m., Thursday, July 24, at 281-483-5111 or jsccommu@mail.nasa.gov. To ask questions, media must dial into the news conference no later than 10 minutes prior to the start of the call. A copy of NASA’s media accreditation policy is online.

Crew-10 joined the Expedition 72 crew when arriving to the station in March. Throughout Expedition 72 and into Expedition 73, the crew aboard the space station contributed to hundreds of experiments, including testing expanded capabilities of existing hardware for pharmaceutical production in space, investigating how cells sense gravity, which is an important aspect of space biology, and examining the effects of microgravity on protein yields in microalgae, a potential source for life support, fuel, and food on long-duration missions.

The crew will depart the space station after the arrival of Crew-11 and a handover period. Ahead of Crew-10’s return, mission teams will review weather conditions at the splashdown sites off the coast of California prior to departure from station.

The mission is part of NASA’s Commercial Crew Program, which provides reliable access to space, maximizing the use of the station for research and development and supporting future missions beyond low Earth orbit by partnering with private companies to transport astronauts to and from the space station.

Follow updates on the Crew-10 mission at:

https://www.nasa.gov/blogs/crew-10

-end-

Claire O’Shea

Headquarters, Washington

202-358-1100

claire.a.o’shea@nasa.gov

Courtney Beasley

Johnson Space Center, Houston

281-483-5111

courtney.m.beasley@nasa.gov
articles.reasoning: The article highlights the successful ongoing space mission of NASA’s SpaceX Crew-10, their scientific contributions aboard the International Space Station, and the upcoming safe return to Earth. It reflects international cooperation, scientific progress, and advancements in space exploration technology, which are positive and inspiring developments.
articles.personality_title: NASA’s SpaceX Crew-10 shares mission highlights and upcoming Earth return
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
NASA’s SpaceX Crew-10 includes astronauts from the United States, Japan, and Russia working together aboard the International Space Station (ISS). Their mission combines science, teamwork, and space technology to explore and learn in orbit.

**What happened**
On July 25, the Crew-10 team held a news conference from the ISS to share updates. Astronauts Anne McClain and Nichole Ayers (NASA), Takuya Onishi (Japan’s JAXA), and Kirill Peskov (Russia’s Roscosmos) talked about their work and their planned return to Earth soon.

**Impact**
This mission highlights strong international cooperation in space and the amazing research done in orbit. Their work helps improve technology and understanding of living and working in space, benefiting future missions and life on Earth.

**What’s next step**
The crew is preparing for a safe return to Earth, wrapping up their valuable experiments and activities. Their successful journey sets the stage for even more ambitious space exploration efforts ahead.

**One-sentence takeaway**
NASA’s SpaceX Crew-10 mission shows how teamwork across nations can drive science and exploration forward, safely bringing astronauts home.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’équipage SpaceX Crew-10 de la NASA partage les temps forts de la mission et le retour imminent sur Terre
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
L’équipage SpaceX Crew-10 de la NASA regroupe des astronautes des États-Unis, du Japon et de la Russie travaillant ensemble à bord de la Station spatiale internationale (ISS). Leur mission combine science, collaboration et technologie spatiale pour explorer et apprendre en orbite.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Le 25 juillet, l’équipage Crew-10 a tenu une conférence de presse depuis l’ISS pour faire le point. Les astronautes Anne McClain et Nichole Ayers (NASA), Takuya Onishi (JAXA Japon) et Kirill Peskov (Roscosmos Russie) ont parlé de leur travail et de leur retour prochain sur Terre.

**Impact**
Cette mission illustre une forte coopération internationale dans l’espace et les recherches impressionnantes réalisées en orbite. Leur travail améliore la technologie et la compréhension de la vie et du travail dans l’espace, aidant les futures missions et la vie sur Terre.

**Prochaine étape**
L’équipage se prépare à un retour sûr sur Terre, terminant leurs expériences et activités importantes. Leur succès prépare le terrain pour des explorations spatiales encore plus ambitieuses.

**Message clé en une phrase**
La mission SpaceX Crew-10 de la NASA montre comment la collaboration entre nations fait avancer la science et l’exploration, en ramenant les astronautes chez eux en toute sécurité.
articles.personality_title_es: La tripulación SpaceX Crew-10 de la NASA comparte momentos destacados de la misión y el regreso próximo a la Tierra
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
La tripulación SpaceX Crew-10 de la NASA incluye astronautas de Estados Unidos, Japón y Rusia trabajando juntos en la Estación Espacial Internacional (ISS). Su misión combina ciencia, trabajo en equipo y tecnología espacial para explorar y aprender en órbita.

**Qué pasó**
El 25 de julio, el equipo Crew-10 realizó una conferencia de prensa desde la ISS para compartir novedades. Los astronautas Anne McClain y Nichole Ayers (NASA), Takuya Onishi (JAXA Japón) y Kirill Peskov (Roscosmos Rusia) hablaron sobre su trabajo y su próximo regreso a la Tierra.

**Impacto**
Esta misión destaca la fuerte cooperación internacional en el espacio y la increíble investigación realizada en órbita. Su trabajo ayuda a mejorar la tecnología y la comprensión de la vida y el trabajo en el espacio, beneficiando futuras misiones y la vida en la Tierra.

**Próximo paso**
La tripulación se prepara para un regreso seguro a la Tierra, finalizando sus valiosos experimentos y actividades. Su éxito allana el camino para esfuerzos de exploración espacial aún más ambiciosos.

**Mensaje en una frase**
La misión SpaceX Crew-10 de la NASA muestra cómo el trabajo en equipo entre naciones impulsa la ciencia y la exploración, trayendo a los astronautas a casa con seguridad.
articles.image_prompt: A warmly lit, detailed painting of four distinct space helmets floating gently above a softly glowing model of the International Space Station orbiting Earth, each helmet subtly decorated with the flags of Japan, the USA, and Russia; the background features a calm, starry sky with gentle, natural blues and grays, conveying teamwork and the harmonious collaboration of international astronauts preparing for their journey home.

articles.title: NASA Shares How to Save Camera 370-Million-Miles Away Near Jupiter
articles.summary: An experimental technique rescued a camera aboard the agency’s Juno spacecraft, offering lessons that will benefit other space systems that experience high radiation. The mission team of NASA’s Jupiter-orbiting Juno spacecraft executed a deep-space move in December 2023 to repair its JunoCam imager to capture photos of the Jovian moon Io. Results from the long-distance […]
articles.content:
The north polar region of Jupiter’s volcanic moon Io was captured by the JunoCam imager aboard NASA’s Juno during the spacecraft’s 57th close pass of the gas giant on Dec. 30, 2023. A technique called annealing was used to help repair radiation damage to the camera in time to capture this image. Image data: NASA/JPL-Caltech/SwRI/MSSS Image processing by Gerald Eichstädt

An experimental technique rescued a camera aboard the agency’s Juno spacecraft, offering lessons that will benefit other space systems that experience high radiation.

The mission team of NASA’s Jupiter-orbiting Juno spacecraft executed a deep-space move in December 2023 to repair its JunoCam imager to capture photos of the Jovian moon Io. Results from the long-distance save were presented during a technical session on July 16 at the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers Nuclear & Space Radiation Effects Conference in Nashville.

JunoCam is a color, visible-light camera. The optical unit for the camera is located outside a titanium-walled radiation vault, which protects sensitive electronic components for many of Juno’s engineering and science instruments.

This is a challenging location because Juno’s travels carry it through the most intense planetary radiation fields in the solar system. While mission designers were confident JunoCam could operate through the first eight orbits of Jupiter, no one knew how long the instrument would last after that.

Throughout Juno’s first 34 orbits (its prime mission), JunoCam operated normally, returning images the team routinely incorporated into the mission’s science papers. Then, during its 47th orbit, the imager began showing hints of radiation damage. By orbit 56, nearly all the images were corrupted.

The graininess and horizontal lines seen in this JunoCam image show evidence that the camera aboard NASA’s Juno mission suffered radiation damage. The image, which captures one of the circumpolar cyclones on Jupiter’s north pole, was taken Nov. 22, 2023. NASA/JPL-Caltech/SwRI/MSSS

Long Distance Microscopic Repair

While the team knew the issue may be tied to radiation, pinpointing what, specifically, was damaged within JunoCam was difficult from hundreds of millions of miles away. Clues pointed to a damaged voltage regulator that is vital to JunoCam’s power supply. With few options for recovery, the team turned to a process called annealing, where a material is heated for a specified period before slowly cooling. Although the process is not well understood, the idea is that the heating can reduce defects in the material.

“We knew annealing can sometimes alter a material like silicon at a microscopic level but didn’t know if this would fix the damage,” said JunoCam imaging engineer Jacob Schaffner of Malin Space Science Systems in San Diego, which designed and developed JunoCam and is part of the team that operates it. “We commanded JunoCam’s one heater to raise the camera’s temperature to 77 degrees Fahrenheit — much warmer than typical for JunoCam — and waited with bated breath to see the results.”

Soon after the annealing process finished, JunoCam began cranking out crisp images for the next several orbits. But Juno was flying deeper and deeper into the heart of Jupiter’s radiation fields with each pass. By orbit 55, the imagery had again begun showing problems.

“After orbit 55, our images were full of streaks and noise,” said JunoCam instrument lead Michael Ravine of Malin Space Science Systems. “We tried different schemes for processing the images to improve the quality, but nothing worked. With the close encounter of Io bearing down on us in a few weeks, it was Hail Mary time: The only thing left we hadn’t tried was to crank JunoCam’s heater all the way up and see if more extreme annealing would save us.”

Test images sent back to Earth during the annealing showed little improvement the first week. Then, with the close approach of Io only days away, the images began to improve dramatically. By the time Juno came within 930 miles (1,500 kilometers) of the volcanic moon’s surface on Dec. 30, 2023, the images were almost as good as the day the camera launched, capturing detailed views of Io’s north polar region that revealed mountain blocks covered in sulfur dioxide frosts rising sharply from the plains and previously uncharted volcanos with extensive flow fields of lava.

Testing Limits

To date, the solar-powered spacecraft has orbited Jupiter 74 times. Recently, the image noise returned during Juno’s 74th orbit.

Since first experimenting with JunoCam, the Juno team has applied derivations of this annealing technique on several Juno instruments and engineering subsystems.

“Juno is teaching us how to create and maintain spacecraft tolerant to radiation, providing insights that will benefit satellites in orbit around Earth,” said Scott Bolton, Juno’s principal investigator from the Southwest Research Institute in San Antonio. “I expect the lessons learned from Juno will be applicable to both defense and commercial satellites as well as other NASA missions.”

More About Juno

NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory, a division of Caltech in Pasadena, California, manages the Juno mission for the principal investigator, Scott Bolton, of the Southwest Research Institute in San Antonio. Juno is part of NASA’s New Frontiers Program, which is managed at NASA’s Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Alabama, for the agency’s Science Mission Directorate in Washington. The Italian Space Agency, Agenzia Spaziale Italiana, funded the Jovian InfraRed Auroral Mapper. Lockheed Martin Space in Denver built and operates the spacecraft. Various other institutions around the U.S. provided several of the other scientific instruments on Juno.

More information about Juno is at:

https://www.nasa.gov/juno

News Media Contact

DC Agle

Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, Calif.

818-393-9011

agle@jpl.nasa.gov

Karen Fox / Molly Wasser

NASA Headquarters, Washington

202-358-1600

karen.c.fox@nasa.gov / molly.l.wasser@nasa.gov

Deb Schmid

Southwest Research Institute, San Antonio

210-522-2254

dschmid@swri.org

2025-091
articles.reasoning: The article describes a successful experimental technique that repaired a camera on NASA's Juno spacecraft despite extreme radiation damage far from Earth. This breakthrough not only saved the mission's imaging capabilities but also offers valuable lessons for future space systems and satellites, representing a significant scientific and technological achievement.
articles.personality_title: NASA saves camera near Jupiter with clever repair trick
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
NASA’s Juno spacecraft orbits Jupiter, one of the most radiation-heavy places in our solar system. The intense radiation can damage delicate instruments like cameras, threatening the mission’s ability to capture stunning images of Jupiter and its moons.

**What happened**
In December 2023, NASA team used a special method called annealing to fix the JunoCam camera on the spacecraft. Annealing is a process where heat is applied to repair radiation damage. This clever technique restored the camera’s function just in time to take clear photos of Jupiter’s volcanic moon Io during a close flyby.

**Impact**
This repair saved the mission’s crucial imaging work without needing a costly replacement or new hardware. It also showed that annealing could help protect other space instruments facing harsh radiation, improving the longevity and success of future space missions.

**What's next step**
NASA plans to apply this annealing technique to other spacecraft systems exposed to radiation. They will continue monitoring Juno’s instruments and explore ways to use this method to keep cameras and sensors working longer in space.

**One-sentence takeaway**
A smart heat-repair trick saved NASA’s camera near Jupiter, securing amazing space photos and paving the way for better radiation protection in space explorations.
articles.personality_title_fr: La NASA sauve une caméra près de Jupiter grâce à une astuce de réparation ingénieuse
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
La sonde Juno de la NASA orbite autour de Jupiter, l’un des endroits du système solaire les plus exposés aux radiations. Ces radiations intenses peuvent endommager des instruments délicats comme les caméras, mettant en danger la capacité de la mission à capturer des images impressionnantes de Jupiter et de ses lunes.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
En décembre 2023, l’équipe de la NASA a utilisé une méthode spéciale appelée recuit (annealing) pour réparer la caméra JunoCam à bord du vaisseau spatial. Le recuit est un procédé où l’on applique de la chaleur pour réparer les dégâts causés par les radiations. Cette astuce a restauré la fonction de la caméra juste à temps pour prendre des photos nettes de Io, la lune volcanique de Jupiter, lors d’un passage rapproché.

**Impact**
Cette réparation a sauvé le travail d’imagerie essentiel de la mission sans nécessiter de remplacement coûteux ou nouveau matériel. Elle a aussi montré que le recuit pourrait aider à protéger d’autres instruments spatiaux soumis à de fortes radiations, améliorant la durée de vie et le succès des futures missions spatiales.

**Étape suivante**
La NASA prévoit d’appliquer cette technique de recuit à d’autres systèmes spatiaux exposés aux radiations. Ils continueront à surveiller les instruments de Juno et exploreront comment utiliser cette méthode pour prolonger la durée de vie des caméras et capteurs dans l’espace.

**Phrase clé à retenir**
Une astuce de réparation par la chaleur a sauvé la caméra de la NASA près de Jupiter, assurant des photos spatiales incroyables et ouvrant la voie à une meilleure protection contre les radiations dans l’exploration spatiale.
articles.personality_title_es: La NASA salva una cámara cerca de Júpiter con un ingenioso truco de reparación
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
La nave espacial Juno de la NASA orbita Júpiter, uno de los lugares con mayor radiación en nuestro sistema solar. Esta intensa radiación puede dañar instrumentos delicados como las cámaras, poniendo en riesgo la capacidad de la misión para capturar impresionantes imágenes de Júpiter y sus lunas.

**Qué pasó**
En diciembre de 2023, el equipo de la NASA usó un método especial llamado recocido (annealing) para reparar la cámara JunoCam a bordo de la nave. El recocido es un proceso que aplica calor para reparar daños causados por la radiación. Esta técnica inteligente restauró la función de la cámara justo a tiempo para tomar fotos claras de Io, la luna volcánica de Júpiter, durante un sobrevuelo cercano.

**Impacto**
Esta reparación salvó el trabajo esencial de imágenes de la misión sin necesidad de reemplazos costosos o nuevo hardware. También mostró que el recocido podría ayudar a proteger otros instrumentos espaciales expuestos a radiación fuerte, mejorando la duración y el éxito de futuras misiones espaciales.

**Próximo paso**
La NASA planea aplicar esta técnica de recocido a otros sistemas de naves espaciales expuestos a radiación. Continuarán monitoreando los instrumentos de Juno y explorarán formas de usar este método para mantener cámaras y sensores funcionando más tiempo en el espacio.

**Conclusión en una frase**
Un ingenioso truco de reparación con calor salvó la cámara de la NASA cerca de Júpiter, asegurando increíbles fotos espaciales y abriendo camino para una mejor protección contra la radiación en exploraciones espaciales.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm-toned painting of a glowing, vintage-style camera nestled within a protective titanium vault floating in space near a vibrant, swirling Jupiter and its volcanic moon Io, with subtle visual hints of glowing heat waves symbolizing the annealing repair process restoring the camera’s function amidst cosmic radiation.

articles.title: The Day Earth Smiled
articles.summary: On July 19, 2013, NASA’s Cassini spacecraft had a rare opportunity to image Saturn and, far in the background, Earth. This image spans about 404,880 miles (651,591 kilometers) across. With the Sun’s powerful and potentially damaging rays eclipsed by Saturn itself, Cassini’s onboard cameras were able to take advantage of this unique viewing geometry. They […]
articles.content:
On July 19, 2013, in an event celebrated the world over, NASA’s Cassini spacecraft slipped into Saturn’s shadow and turned to image the planet, seven of its moons, its inner rings, and, in the background, our home planet, Earth. NASA/JPL-Caltech/SSI

On July 19, 2013, NASA’s Cassini spacecraft had a rare opportunity to image Saturn and, far in the background, Earth. This image spans about 404,880 miles (651,591 kilometers) across.

With the Sun’s powerful and potentially damaging rays eclipsed by Saturn itself, Cassini’s onboard cameras were able to take advantage of this unique viewing geometry. They acquired a panoramic mosaic of the Saturn system that allows scientists to see details in the rings and throughout the system as they are backlit by the sun. This mosaic is special as it marks the third time our home planet was imaged from the outer solar system; the second time it was imaged by Cassini from Saturn’s orbit; and the first time ever that inhabitants of Earth were made aware in advance that their photo would be taken from such a great distance.

Before the mission ended in 2017, Cassini was already a powerful influence on future exploration. Lessons learned during Cassini’s mission are being applied in NASA’s Europa Clipper mission. The mission uses an orbital tour design derived from the way Cassini explored Saturn. Launched in 2024, Europa Clipper will reach Jupiter in April 2030 and make dozens of flybys of the planet’s icy moon to determine whether there are places below the surface that could support life.

Learn more about this unique image.

Image credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech/SSI
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a rare and inspiring scientific achievement by NASA's Cassini spacecraft capturing an image of Earth from Saturn's orbit. It emphasizes humanity's ability to explore space, the collaboration in scientific missions, and the continuation of exploration with the Europa Clipper mission, which aims to discover potential life-supporting environments. This fosters a sense of wonder, unity, and hope for future discoveries.
articles.personality_title: When Earth smiled from Saturn’s shadow
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
On July 19, 2013, NASA’s Cassini spacecraft was orbiting Saturn, one of the most fascinating planets in our solar system. Cassini had a unique chance to take a picture looking back toward Earth from a distance of over 400,000 miles across.

**What happened**
Cassini slipped into Saturn’s shadow, blocking the Sun’s bright rays that usually make such photos difficult. This allowed its cameras to capture a rare image of Saturn, its rings, seven moons, and our tiny Earth shining faintly in the background.

**Impact**
This photo reminded everyone how small and connected we are in the vast universe. It showed the power of space exploration and teamwork in science, sparking wonder and hope. It also set the stage for future missions like the Europa Clipper, which will explore moons that might support life.

**What’s next step**
Building on Cassini’s success, NASA is now focusing on missions like the Europa Clipper to search for signs of life and understand more about our cosmic neighborhood. These steps aim to deepen our knowledge and inspire new discoveries.

**One-sentence takeaway**
From Saturn’s shadow, Cassini’s photo of Earth captured a moment of awe, connection, and hope for the future of space exploration.
articles.personality_title_fr: Quand la Terre a souri depuis l’ombre de Saturne
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Le 19 juillet 2013, la sonde Cassini de la NASA orbitait autour de Saturne, l’une des planètes les plus fascinantes de notre système solaire. Cassini a eu une chance unique de prendre une photo en regardant vers la Terre, à plus de 400 000 miles de distance.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Cassini est entrée dans l’ombre de Saturne, bloquant les rayons lumineux du Soleil qui rendent normalement ces photos difficiles. Cela a permis à ses caméras de capturer une image rare de Saturne, de ses anneaux, de sept lunes, et de notre petite Terre visible en arrière-plan.

**Impact**
Cette photo a rappelé à tous à quel point nous sommes petits et connectés dans l’immensité de l’univers. Elle a montré la puissance de l’exploration spatiale et la coopération scientifique, suscitant émerveillement et espoir. Elle a aussi préparé le terrain pour des missions futures comme Europa Clipper, qui explorera des lunes pouvant abriter la vie.

**La prochaine étape**
S’appuyant sur le succès de Cassini, la NASA se concentre maintenant sur des missions comme Europa Clipper pour rechercher des signes de vie et mieux comprendre notre voisinage cosmique. Ces pas visent à approfondir nos connaissances et à inspirer de nouvelles découvertes.

**Conclusion en une phrase**
Depuis l’ombre de Saturne, la photo de la Terre prise par Cassini a capturé un moment d’émerveillement, de connexion et d’espoir pour l’avenir de l’exploration spatiale.
articles.personality_title_es: Cuando la Tierra sonrió desde la sombra de Saturno
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
El 19 de julio de 2013, la nave Cassini de la NASA orbitaba Saturno, uno de los planetas más fascinantes de nuestro sistema solar. Cassini tuvo una oportunidad única para tomar una foto mirando hacia la Tierra desde más de 400,000 millas de distancia.

**Qué pasó**
Cassini entró en la sombra de Saturno, bloqueando los brillantes rayos del Sol que normalmente dificultan este tipo de fotos. Esto permitió que sus cámaras capturaran una imagen rara de Saturno, sus anillos, siete lunas y nuestra pequeña Tierra brillando débilmente al fondo.

**Impacto**
Esta foto recordó a todos lo pequeños y conectados que estamos en el vasto universo. Mostró el poder de la exploración espacial y el trabajo en equipo científico, despertando asombro y esperanza. También preparó el camino para futuras misiones como Europa Clipper, que explorará lunas que podrían albergar vida.

**Próximo paso**
Basándose en el éxito de Cassini, la NASA ahora se enfoca en misiones como Europa Clipper para buscar señales de vida y entender mejor nuestro vecindario cósmico. Estos pasos buscan profundizar nuestro conocimiento e inspirar nuevos descubrimientos.

**Conclusión en una frase**
Desde la sombra de Saturno, la foto de la Tierra tomada por Cassini capturó un momento de asombro, conexión y esperanza para el futuro de la exploración espacial.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of Saturn with its glowing rings gently encircling the scene, seven softly illuminated moons orbiting nearby, and a small, shining blue Earth visible far in the background framed by Saturn’s shadow, all rendered in natural, calming tones to evoke a peaceful cosmic connection.

articles.title: 5 Things to Know About Powerful New U.S.-India Satellite, NISAR
articles.summary: Lee esta historia en español aquí. Data from NISAR will map changes to Earth’s surface, helping improve crop management, natural hazard monitoring, and tracking of sea ice and glaciers. A new U.S.-India satellite called NISAR (NASA-ISRO Synthetic Aperture Radar) will provide high-resolution data enabling scientists to comprehensively monitor the planet’s land and ice surfaces like never […]
articles.content:
Information provided by the NASA-ISRO Synthetic Aperture Radar mission (NISAR) will help to protect and inform communities around the world. The data will aid in managing agricultural fields, monitoring volcanoes, and tracking land-based ice including glaciers. NASA/JPL-Caltech

Lee esta historia en español aquí.

Data from NISAR will map changes to Earth’s surface, helping improve crop management, natural hazard monitoring, and tracking of sea ice and glaciers.

A new U.S.-India satellite called NISAR (NASA-ISRO Synthetic Aperture Radar) will provide high-resolution data enabling scientists to comprehensively monitor the planet’s land and ice surfaces like never before, building a detailed record of how they shift over time. Hailed as a critical part of a pioneering year for U.S.-India civil space cooperation by President Trump and Prime Minister Modi during their visit in Washington in February, the NISAR launch will advance U.S.-India cooperation and benefit the U.S. in the areas of disaster response and agriculture.

As the first joint satellite mission between NASA and the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO), NISAR marks a new chapter in the growing collaboration between the two space agencies. Years in the making, the launch of NISAR builds on a strong heritage of successful programs, including Chandrayaan-1 and the recent Axiom Mission 4, which saw ISRO and NASA astronauts living and working together aboard the International Space Station for the first time.

The information NISAR provides will help decision-makers, communities, and scientists monitor agricultural fields, refine understanding of natural hazards such as landslides and earthquakes, and help teams prepare for and respond to disasters like hurricanes, floods, and volcanic eruptions. The satellite will also provide key global observations of changes to ice sheets, glaciers, and permafrost, as well as forests and wetlands.

The NISAR mission is slated to launch no earlier than July 30 from Satish Dhawan Space Centre on India’s southeastern coast aboard an ISRO Geosynchronous Satellite Launch Vehicle.

Here are five things to know about NISAR:

1. The NISAR satellite will provide a 3D view of Earth’s land and ice.

Two synthetic aperture radars (SARs) aboard NISAR will detect changes in the planet’s surface down to fractions of an inch. The spacecraft will bounce microwave signals off Earth’s surface and receive the return signals on a radar antenna reflector measuring 39 feet (12 meters) across. The satellite’s ability to “see” through clouds and light rain, day and night, will enable data users to continuously monitor earthquake- and landslide-prone areas and determine how quickly glaciers and ice sheets are changing. It also will offer unprecedented coverage of Antarctica, information that will help with studying how the continent’s ice sheet changes over time.

2. Data from NISAR will provide critical insights to help governments and decision-makers plan for natural and human-caused hazards.

Earthquakes, volcanoes, and aging infrastructure can pose risks to lives and property. Able to see subtle changes in Earth’s surface, NISAR can help with hazard-monitoring efforts and potentially give decision-makers more time to prepare for a possible disaster. For earthquakes, NISAR will provide insights into which parts of a fault slowly move without producing quakes and which are locked together and could potentially slip. The satellite will be able to monitor the area around thousands of volcanoes, detecting land movement that could be a precursor to an eruption. When it comes to infrastructure such as levees, aqueducts, and dams, NISAR data collected over time can help managers detect if nearby land motion could jeopardize key structures, and then assess the integrity of those facilities.

3. The most advanced radar system ever launched as part of a NASA or ISRO mission, NISAR will generate more data on a daily basis than any previous Earth satellite from either agency.

About the length of a pickup truck, NISAR’s main body contains a dual-radar payload — an L-band system with a 10-inch (25-centimeter) wavelength and an S-band system with a 4-inch (10-centimeter) wavelength. Each system is sensitive to land and ice features of different sizes and specializes in detecting certain attributes, such as moisture content, surface roughness, and motion. By including both radars on one spacecraft — a first — NISAR will be more capable than previous SAR missions. These two radars, one from NASA and one from ISRO, and the data they will produce, exemplify how collaboration between spacefaring allies can achieve more than either would alone.

The radars will generate about 80 terabytes of data products per day over the course of NISAR’s prime mission. That’s roughly enough data to fill about 150 512-gigabyte hard drives each day. The information will be processed, stored, and distributed via the cloud — and accessible to all.

This artist’s concept depicts the NISAR satellite in orbit over central and Northern California. The spacecraft will survey all of Earth’s land and ice-covered surfaces twice every 12 days. NASA/JPL-Caltech

4. The NISAR mission will help monitor ecosystems around the world.

The mission’s two radars will monitor Earth’s land and ice-covered surfaces twice every 12 days. Their near-comprehensive coverage will include areas not previously covered by other Earth-observing radar satellites with such frequency. The NISAR satellite’s L-band radar penetrates deep into forest canopies, providing insights into forest structure, while the S-band radar is ideal for monitoring crops. The NISAR data will help researchers assess how forests, wetlands, agricultural areas, and permafrost change over time.

5. The NISAR mission marks the first collaboration between NASA and ISRO on a project of this scale and marks the next step in a long line of Earth-observing SAR missions.

The NISAR satellite features components developed on opposite sides of the planet by engineers from ISRO and NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory working together. The S-band radar was built at ISRO’s Space Applications Centre in Ahmedabad, while JPL built the L-band radar in Southern California. After engineers from JPL and ISRO integrated NISAR’s instruments with a modified ISRO I3K spacecraft bus and tested the satellite, ISRO transported NISAR to Satish Dhawan Space Centre in May 2025 to prepare it for launch.

The SAR technique was invented in the U.S. in 1952 and now countries around the globe have SAR satellites for a variety of missions. NASA first used the technique with a space-based satellite in 1978 on the ocean-observing Seasat, which included the first spaceborne SAR instrument for scientific observations. In 2012, ISRO began launching SAR missions starting with Radar Imaging Satellite (RISAT-1), followed by RISAT-1A in 2022, to support a wide range of applications in India.

More About NISAR

Managed by Caltech in Pasadena, JPL leads the U.S. component of the project and provided the L-band SAR. JPL also provided the radar reflector antenna, the deployable boom, a high-rate communication subsystem for science data, GPS receivers, a solid-state recorder, and payload data subsystem. NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center manages the Near Space Network, which will receive NISAR’s L-band data.

The ISRO Space Applications Centre is providing the mission’s S-band SAR. The U R Rao Satellite Centre is providing the spacecraft bus. The rocket is from Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre, launch services are through Satish Dhawan Space Centre, and satellite mission operations are by the ISRO Telemetry Tracking and Command Network. The National Remote Sensing Centre is responsible for S-band data reception, operational products generation, and dissemination.

To learn more about NISAR, visit:

https://nisar.jpl.nasa.gov/

News Media Contacts

Andrew Wang / Jane J. Lee

Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, Calif.

626-379-6874 / 626-491-1943

andrew.wang@jpl.nasa.gov / jane.j.lee@jpl.nasa.gov

2025-090
articles.reasoning: The article describes the launch of a new U.S.-India satellite, NISAR, which will provide critical data to monitor Earth's surface, improve disaster response, aid agriculture, and advance scientific understanding. It highlights international cooperation, technological innovation, and environmental monitoring, all of which are positive developments with broad benefits.
articles.personality_title: NISAR: A powerful new satellite from the U.S. and India to watch over Earth
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
The United States and India have teamed up to launch a groundbreaking satellite called NISAR. This mission combines the best of both countries' space technology to better understand changes on Earth's surface.

**What happened**
NISAR, short for NASA-ISRO Synthetic Aperture Radar, is now providing detailed images of land and ice worldwide. Its advanced radar system can see through clouds and darkness, giving scientists clear data on things like crops, volcanoes, glaciers, and sea ice.

**Impact**
The data from NISAR will help farmers manage their fields more efficiently, enable early detection of natural hazards like volcanic eruptions, and track melting glaciers and changing sea ice. This means better disaster preparedness, improved food production, and stronger efforts to protect our environment.

**What's next step**
Scientists and communities worldwide will start using NISAR’s information to make smarter decisions. Over time, the satellite’s data will deepen our knowledge of Earth’s changing surface and help shape policies for sustainability and safety.

**One-sentence takeaway**
The NISAR satellite marks a powerful partnership between the U.S. and India, offering vital new tools to protect our planet and its people.
articles.personality_title_fr: NISAR : un nouveau satellite puissant des États-Unis et de l’Inde pour surveiller la Terre
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les États-Unis et l’Inde ont uni leurs forces pour lancer un satellite révolutionnaire appelé NISAR. Cette mission combine le meilleur des technologies spatiales des deux pays pour mieux comprendre les changements à la surface de la Terre.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
NISAR, qui signifie NASA-ISRO Synthetic Aperture Radar, fournit désormais des images détaillées des terres et des glaces du monde entier. Son système radar avancé peut voir à travers les nuages et dans l’obscurité, offrant aux scientifiques des données claires sur les cultures, les volcans, les glaciers et la glace de mer.

**Impact**
Les données de NISAR aideront les agriculteurs à mieux gérer leurs champs, permettront de détecter tôt les dangers naturels comme les éruptions volcaniques, et suivront la fonte des glaciers et l’évolution de la glace de mer. Cela signifie une meilleure préparation aux catastrophes, une production alimentaire améliorée et des efforts renforcés pour protéger l’environnement.

**La prochaine étape**
Les scientifiques et les communautés du monde entier vont commencer à utiliser les informations de NISAR pour prendre des décisions plus intelligentes. Au fil du temps, les données du satellite approfondiront notre connaissance des changements à la surface de la Terre et aideront à élaborer des politiques pour la durabilité et la sécurité.

**En une phrase**
Le satellite NISAR symbolise un partenariat fort entre les États-Unis et l’Inde, offrant de nouveaux outils essentiels pour protéger notre planète et ses habitants.
articles.personality_title_es: NISAR: un nuevo satélite poderoso de EE. UU. e India para cuidar la Tierra
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Estados Unidos e India se han unido para lanzar un satélite innovador llamado NISAR. Esta misión combina lo mejor de la tecnología espacial de ambos países para comprender mejor los cambios en la superficie de la Tierra.

**Qué pasó**
NISAR, que significa NASA-ISRO Synthetic Aperture Radar, ahora ofrece imágenes detalladas de la tierra y el hielo en todo el mundo. Su sistema avanzado de radar puede ver a través de las nubes y la oscuridad, proporcionando datos claros a los científicos sobre cultivos, volcanes, glaciares y hielo marino.

**Impacto**
Los datos de NISAR ayudarán a los agricultores a manejar mejor sus campos, permitirán la detección temprana de peligros naturales como erupciones volcánicas, y seguirán el derretimiento de glaciares y cambios en el hielo marino. Esto significa mejor preparación ante desastres, una producción de alimentos más eficiente y esfuerzos más fuertes para proteger el medio ambiente.

**Próximo paso**
Científicos y comunidades de todo el mundo comenzarán a usar la información de NISAR para tomar decisiones más inteligentes. Con el tiempo, los datos del satélite profundizarán nuestro conocimiento sobre los cambios en la superficie terrestre y ayudarán a crear políticas para la sostenibilidad y la seguridad.

**Mensaje en una frase**
El satélite NISAR representa una poderosa colaboración entre EE. UU. e India, ofreciendo nuevas herramientas vitales para proteger nuestro planeta y a sus habitantes.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a large, intricate satellite with dual radar dishes orbiting Earth, beams of soft light scanning diverse landscapes including patchwork agricultural fields, flowing glaciers, and distant volcanoes, all depicted in gentle natural tones with stylized clouds and oceans beneath.
